key_points: The owner of the Ever Given blames the Suez Canal Authority (SCA) for the ship's grounding in March.
The vessel was stuck for six days, disrupting global trade by blocking the canal.
Ever Given has been detained as the SCA seeks a $916.5m compensation claim.
Hearings over the ship’s detention and the compensation claim took place at the Ismailia economic court.
The ship's owner, Shoei Kisen, appeals against the detention and contests the SCA's claim.
Lawyers for Shoei Kisen argue the SCA allowed the ship to enter in bad weather and failed to provide adequate tug boat support.
Recordings showed disagreements among SCA pilots and the control center regarding the ship entering the canal.
The SCA's actions are described as not qualifying as a 'salvage operation' under legal definitions, challenging the basis for compensation.
Shoei Kisen seeks $100,000 in initial compensation for detention-related losses.
A court decision on the case is expected on Sunday.
spokespersons: Ahmed Abu Ali (Member of the legal team representing Shoei Kisen)
